Title: David S. Kottcamp
Comment:
To whom it may concern:

I was recently bumped from a flight, and the airline's next flight with an available 
seat would have gotten me to my destination after the meeting I was flying out to 
attend.  As such, I cancelled my flight, was reimburst for the ticket, and was 
offered a voucher for my 'troubles'.  I accepted the offer, not having any idea what 
my alternatives were.

Regardless of what changes you make with regards to adjusting the 
compensation to involuntarily bumped travelers (suggestion below), I think airlines 
should be required to verbally (not in fine print) inform bumped passengers of what 
their rights are given their situation.  Having read up on this after the fact, it is not 
too onerous of an ask on airlines.  For example, they should have told me I was 
entitled to $400 compensation (I'm assuming this means a $400 check), but was 
only offered a travel voucher for another ticket.

With regards to compensation: while I like the idea of an auction, whereby the 
airline would pay whatever it takes until all seats have been voluntarily given up to 
those who want to be on said flight; it would be far too onerous on airlines to 
execute, and would probably only increase the times it takes to load a plane.

I think a straight forward 100% of total ticket value for a 1-2 hr delay and 200% of 
ticket face value for a >2 hr delay, WITH NO CAPS, would be a very straight 
forward way to ensure passengers are adequately covered for their troubles.  This 
approach also ensures that you won't have to waste tax payers money revising 
the figures again in a few years after inflation has erroded the new caps, they'll 
automatically adjust as prices go up.

While some would object to this on the grounds that airlines will then prioritize 
highest paying customers over lower paying, it has two benefits: 1) it aligns with 
the airlines priority of maximizing profit by minimizing losses and 2) people are 
paying for convenience; if it is communicated at the time of purchase that cheaper 
tickets are more likely to face a 'bump' than more expensive tickets, passengers 
can choose how important it is to get there on time.

Regards,
David Kottcamp

Title: Robert A. Browning
Comment:
I support raising the maximum amount that the airlines have to pay a customer
denied a seat due to overbooking.  In addition, I support requiring the airlines
to pay any other costs incurred by the customer as a result of being denied a
seat on a flight.  For example, someone going on a short 3 or 4 day getaway
vacation who is denied a seat but manages to get a flight the next day has been
greatly inconvenienced.  The customer has had to pay, in advance, a
non-refundable hotel bill that has now been partially unused.  Also, the
customer may have their vacation ruined due to the loss of time spent on
vacation that was short to begin with.

I really would like to support even stricter rules.  I would like to eliminate
the practice of overbooking entirely.  Most airfares cannot be canceled at a
late date, with the expectation of getting any money back (tickets are
non-refundable).  Therefore, the airlines should in general be required to not
sell more seats than they have, they are compensated already should the traveler
cancel.

Title: Angela Palazuelos
Comment:
1. Question Nine: MINIMAL PROTECTION: I urge the DOJ to remove the phrase
"minimal protection" from the new definition of a Service Animal. "Protection"
means aggression training in the dog industry; this will lead to misinterpretation.
2. Question Ten: OTHER SPECIES: I ask the Department to consider establishing
guidelines that would limit the use of other species only to animals who can be
trained to meet the same standards for behavior and training that assistance
dogs must meet to qualify for public access.
3. Question Eleven: A SIZE OR WEIGHT LIMIT: I oppose a size or weight limitation
on common domestic animals like assistance dogs! It would discriminate against
disabled persons whose weight, height and/or the severity of their mobility
impairment necessitates that they work with a dog of a breed of sufficient size
and strength to prevent falls or perform other tasks without injury to the dog.
4. Problem: The DO WORK phrase in the Definition: I urge the Department to
eliminate the "do work" phrase in the proposed Definition and continue to
include the requirement that service animals must be individually trained to
perform "tasks" for the benefit of a disabled individual.

Title: Association of Flight Attendants-CWA, AFL-CIO
Comment:
Comments of 
The Association of Flight Attendants-CWA, AFL-CIO
Docket Number OST-2003-15245
Submitted September 25, 2008
Via Federal eRulemaking Portal

The Association of Flight Attendants-CWA, AFL-CIO, which represents 55,000 
Flight Attendants at 20 airlines, applauds the Department of Transportation’s 
postponement of 40.67(b) to allow for a formal comment period on its proposal to 
make direct observation testing mandatory, rather than discretionary, for return to 
duty and follow up drug testing.  We hope that our comments will be considered 
and that DOT will eliminate this proposed rule change in its entirety. 

Before we share our concerns specifically about 40.67(b), we offer our concerns 
about the August 25, 2008 change to the direct observation (DO) collection 
procedure which requires prosthetic device inspections for authorized and 
mandatory DO test situations.   Given that prosthetic device inspections will be a 
part of return to duty and follow up testing if 40.76 (b) is adopted, our objections 
should be considered. 

We oppose the August 25, 2008 inclusion of a prosthetic device check for all 
direct observation collections described in 40.67 (i).  DOT made this change 
without a formal notice of propose rule making and without a formal public 
comment period.  In the Federal Register Vol. 73 No. 166 page 50225, DOT 
states that the department “explicitly sought comments in its October 2005 
Notice of Proposed Rule Making (NPRM) on whether collectors should check to 
make sure that employees providing a specimen under DO are not using a 
prosthetic device to cheat on the test (e.g. by having an employee lower his pants 
and underwear so that the collector or observer could determine whether the 
employee was using such a device)”. This request for comments was in the 
NPRM but it was not in direct response to a notice of proposed change.  

In the October 2005 NPRM, DOT actually asked, “Would it be appropriate to 
require that collectors and observers, as appropriate, check for these devices by 
having male employees lower their pants and underwear just before observed 
collections take place?”  Procedurally and in spirit, this “explicit opportunity” could 
best be characterized as a request for an initial reaction to the use of prosthetic 
device inspections just for men, only as appropriate, and requiring limited frontal 
exposure.  AFA believes that expanding the DO process to include mandatory 
prosthetic device  inspections for all employees with a naked pirouette is such a 
significant departure from DOT’s prior DO collection and from all other regulated 
collections that a formal comment period should have been afforded.  Witholding a 
NPRM and formal comment period for 40.67(i) demonstrates an extreme 
insensitivity towards and devaluation of personal privacy and dignity. 

The rationale that DOT has offered for the implementation of 40.67 (i) is that 
prosthetic checks are necessary to safeguard the integrity of the drug testing 
process.  According to DOT, the increasing availability of prosthetic devices on 
the internet suggests that the integrity of the drug testing process is 
compromised.  However, DOT has offered no evidence to substantiate any 
relationship between the availability and/or number of prosthetic devices on the 
internet and acts of drug test cheating by DOT safety sensitive employees. While 
the Association of Flight Attendants-CWA is a full supporter of ensuring optimal 
safety for our members and the flying public, we believe that alternate measures 
exist for ensuring the integrity of the drug testing process.  Improved collector 
training, enforcement of existing collection safeguards and legislative action which 
bans the sale of substances or devices used to beat drug tests are three such 
measures that are reasonable and achievable without compromising testing 
integrity and the dignity of the person being tested.  

Part of the rationale that DOT has offered for the immediate implementation of 
40.67 (i) is that direct observation occurs in only a very small percentage of DOT 
test situations.  While this is an accurate characterization today, it is a 
misrepresentation of what the future holds should 40.67 (b) be implemented.  If 
DO collections are required for drug tests conducted as a part of the return to duty 
process (which minimally includes 1 return to duty drug test, at least 6 follow up 
tests in year 1 of return to work and an unlimited and unspecified number of follow 
up tests in years 2 through 5) then the number of direct observation tests will be 
significant.   

Under existing DOT requirements, every employee who has a verified positive drug 
test result on any type of test (including pre-employment, random, post accident, 
and reasonable cause/suspicion) whether for alcohol and/or drugs, is subject to 
return to duty and follow up drug testing based on the formula explained above 
regardless whether the DOT violator returns to their existing employer or finds 
another employer.  Alcohol test violators could also be included in the potential 
pool of return to duty and follow up drug tests since Substance Abuse 
Professionals are authorized to require drug testing in the return to duty testing 
plan for alcohol violators. 

Given that the current drug test positive rate for safety sensitive employees is  2% 
and there are approximately 12,000,000 DOT safety sensitive employees, it is 
estimated that up to 240,000  employees could be subject to 40.67 (b) procedures 
each year.  In the first year of return to safety sensitive duty, this potential pool of 
240,000 employees (which does not include alcohol test positives) would 
minimally be required to submit to   1,680,000 DO tests.  Given the potential 
number of drug tests subject to 40.67(b) and 40.67 (i) as well as the potential 
administrative and cost burdens associated with these changes, (including donor 
and observer gender matching and lost productivity), the DO requirement for return 
to duty and follow-up testing is an unreasonable assault on employee privacy and 
business margins.  

An added and unfortunate result of 40.67 (b) may also be employer retrenchment 
from offering employment, reemployment and/or continuing employment to those 
who have completed a rehabilitation/education process.
 
Recently, the Government Accounting Office (GAO) reported that 75% of 
inspected drug testing collection sites failed to secure their facility from 
substances that could be used to adulterate or dilute a drug test specimen.  For 
example, sixty-seven percent (67%) of the sites failed to secure all sources of 
water in the restroom so specimens could not be diluted.   Forty-two percent 
(42%) did not ask employees to empty her/his pockets to ensure that no items 
were present that could be used to adulterate specimens.  Nineteen percent 
(19%) failed to check the temperature of the specimen.  These are simple and 
very basic DOT collection procedures established to safeguard the integrity of the 
testing process against cheating.  Adding a controversial and time consuming 
procedure like DO collections when collectors are already struggling to comply 
with existing safeguards will surely burden an already troubled collection system.  

The Association of Flight Attendants-CWA challenges the need for 40.67 (b) and 
40.67 (i).   As reported in Quest’s 2007 Drug Testing Index, drug use by safety 
sensitive employees is at an historic low.  The positive rate for safety sensitive 
employees is currently measured at 2% which is down from 2.5% in 2002.  Safety 
sensitive employees have a 250% lower drug test positive rate compared to the 
general US workforce.  Over the past five years, reliable data proves that there has 
been no significant change in the rate of tampering with drug tests by safety 
sensitive employees as evidenced by Quest’s non-negative specimen validity test 
results between 2002 and 2006.  In fact, non-negative rates by oxidizing 
adulterants have dropped 500% from .05% in 2002 to 0% in 2006.  The low 
positive and even lower adulteration and substitution rates for safety sensitive 
employees offer evidence that there is no compelling public need for 40.67 (b) and 
40.67(i).  

Of paramount concern to the Association of Flight Attendants –CWA are the 
prejudicial thinking and proposed discriminatory practices underpinning DOT’s 
40.67(b).  According to the Department, substance abusing and/or dependent 
rehabilitated employees, as a group, are at higher risk of tampering with their drug 
test specimens than the rest of the workforce  because they have a heightened 
motivation to cheat on their  return to duty and follow up tests  should they 
experience a relapse which would jeopardize their jobs if detected.   Therefore, 
40.67 (b) proposes that these employees should be subject to direct observation 
testing for all return to duty and all follow up drug tests.   In unraveling this multi-
speculative thinking, the Association of Flight Attendants-CWA offers the below 
objections.    

Employees who test positive have statistically demonstrated a higher propensity 
towards honesty in the drug testing process than one can logically ascribe to the 
general DOT drug testing population. They submitted their dirty urines for testing 
rather than adulterate or substitute it.  

Safeguards are already built into the return to duty process to address relapse.  
Those safeguards include an initial and return to duty substance abuse evaluation 
by a professional, mandatory education and/or treatment, and unannounced and 
accelerated testing for up to five years.  Moreover, there has been no evidence or 
documentation put forth by the DOT demonstrating that the DOT return to duty 
process needs fixing or enhancing.   

Rehabilitated employees who are returned to work after a test positive must 
remain clean as a part of their continuing employment.  Conditional employment 
actually serves as a protective factor not as a relapse factor. Recovery rates are 
significantly higher for employer monitored rehabilitated employees than the 
general population.  

While employers have been authorized to conduct DO collections  for  return to 
duty and follow up tests, their petitions to postpone the implementation of 40.67 
(b) and 40.67 (i) suggests that they rarely, if ever, utilized this invasive 
procedure.   

All other DOT mandated DO collections are based on evidence (either a lab test 
result or an observed behavior) that one donor during one collection may have 
cheated on one drug test.  Additionally, this donor is not automatically subject to 
DO testing on future tests.  However, in 40.67 (b) the DOT proposes that all 
individuals who belong to the group of successfully rehabilitated employees must 
be subject to DO testing on all occasions because of fears rather than evidence.  

AFA-CWA vigorously opposes direct observation testing and any enhancement to 
and/ or expansion of that process as proposed in 40.67 (b) and implemented in 
40.67 (i).    DOT has not provided any measurable evidence to support the notion 
that cheating is on the rise or that cheating cannot be contained by existing 
collection safeguards when followed.  The mere availability of internet devices 
does not justify the erosion of personal privacy for millions of DOT safety sensitive 
employees.   

Using items displayed on the internet as a rationale for significant procedural 
changes and ignoring empirical data from established and certified laboratories is 
a troubling precedent. 

Requiring rehabilitated employees to submit to DO testing for all return to duty 
and follow up tests is a discriminatory policy which mandates unreasonable 
searches.
  
We request that you rescind 40.67 (b) and 40.67 (i).  We ask that you identify non-
invasive measures to protect the integrity of the testing process, like improved 
collector training, enforcement of existing safeguards and legislative initiatives to 
ban drug test tampering devices. This is the best path to ensuring the integrity of 
our drug testing process and ensuring the safety of our transportation system.  
This also is the path recommended by the GAO in its recent report on collection 
safeguards.  

Thank You,

Patricia Friend, International President
Association of Flight Attendants-CWA, AFL-CIO
501 Third St. NW
Washington, D.C.  20001

Title: Susan Clark
Comment:
I have been providing DOT drug test training and consulting for over 16 years.  
During this time, attempts to "beat" the drug test have increased significantly.  
Drug abusers will go to any length to continue using, therefore those who have 
tested positive in the past, and who continue to abuse drugs, are motivated by 
their addiction to adulterate, substitute, or use prosthetic-type devices to provide 
a "clean" specimen at the collection site.  Direct observation drug collections that 
took place prior to 8/25/08 did not effectively deter such individuals because real-
looking prosthetic devices could successfully be used without detection by the 
observer.  Therefore I believe DOT has taken appropriate and justifiable actions to 
combat the problem.  

Revised direct observation collection procedures create increased responsibilities 
for the direct observer.  Observed collections have always been awkward, and will 
continue to be so.  Collectors, and individuals they designate as observers, should 
be given crystal clear guidance on how to conduct these collections.  DOT has 
made a good effort at providing guidance for collectors and observers.  Our 
company, Alpha Pro Solutions, a national drug and alcohol test training 
organization, has taken additional steps including providing a suggested 
verbatim "script" to our clients with recommended communication and observation 
techniques in line with DOT requirements.  Unfortunately, I believe some collection 
sites will gloss over the revised DOT observation regulations, and will not 
implement proper "update" training of collectors.  Therefore, I believe "update" 
training should be mandatory, with a specific training agenda provided by DOT, 
and a mock proficiency requirement as part of the required update training.  I 
believe collector role-play scenarios will greatly increase the level of 
professionalism and accuracy that should be exhibited by each trained collector 
and/or their designated observer.  I do not believe we should assume that 
collectors who have been "told" about the revised procedures have a practical 
understanding of how and when observed collections should be properly 
conducted. 

Regarding mandatory Return-to-Duty and Follow-Up testing observed collections, I 
believe this requirement is prudent and appropriate given the individuals' former 
attempts to "beat" the DOT drug-free rules by either refusing to test, or by 
providing a positive, adulterated, or substituted specimen.  Mandatory direct 
observation collections for RTD and FUP testing is truly a deterrant, and in line 
with the intent of the Transportation Workplace Drug Testing Program.  

Lastly, I believe DOT should strongly consider making additional drugs of abuse 
(namely drugs available by prescription but abused) part of the mandatory 
substance abuse testing panel.  

Respectfully and in support of DOT drug test revised regulations, 
Sue Clark

Title: Service Dog Central
Comment:
Requiring special documentation for people with one disability, but not of those
with other disabilities is just as discriminatory as treating people with
disabilities differently than those without disabilities.

Permitting emotional support animals in aircraft is problematic because the
animals are not necessarily temperamentally suited to be in that type of
stressful situation, or trained to behave properly including toileting and how
they interact with other passengers.  However, in order to permit emotional
support animals on aircraft, the DOT established a policy of asking for
documentation for the animal, not of temperament or training (for the purposes
of protecting the public safety) but of proof of disability (for the purposes of
discouraging pet owners).

Many pet owners have already figured out it is easy to ask their family doctor
for a note so they can take their show dog or pet in the cabin with them. 
Requiring additional documentation of another type of animal, a psychiatric
service animal, will not decrease the number of pets in the cabin for this reason.

Many others have discovered they can get their pets "certified" as a service
animal by merely claiming that it is one and paying a $40-$50 fee over the
internet, to organizations such as SARA.  

The DOT also established the opportunity for airline employees to ask the owner
of an animal for credible assurances the animal is indeed a service animal. 
That can include asking precisely what the dog is trained to do.  This is an
accepted method for determining whether a given dog is a service dog in other
public accommodations covered by the ACAA's sister law, the ADA.

If the DOT wants to seriously curtail false claims of pets as service dogs, they
should 1) notify airlines they may ignore documentation from known "diploma
mills" such as SARA and base their determinations solely on credible verbal
assurances rather than "certification" and 2) create penalties for pet owners
shown to have made a false claim that a pet is a service animal.

People with psychiatric disabilities are already singled out in our society
because of the nature of their disease.  Many consider them mentally weak or
simply lazy.  Others consider them down-right dangerous.  Solely because of
their disability.  It is the very worst kind of discrimination because it is so
socially accepted that most do not recognize it as discrimination.

People with mental disabilities should not be singled out for special
examination and the humiliation of being treated inferior to others with other
disabilities.  Of all disabilities, those with psychiatric disabilities are most
negatively impacted by being put under undue emotional stress.  They would be
forced into the very situations they find difficult to manage because of their
disability.

Presumably this discrimination would further be perpetrated by employees making
value judgments on whether a given dog might be a service dog based on its breed
or size.  Therefore, those with disabilities other than mental illness who
coincidentally use service dogs of unusual breeds or sizes, will also be
subjected to additional inspection.

What, then, will be the consequence if a person with, say, a Papillion service
dog is asked for a letter from their doctor because the employee thinks that a
Papillion couldn't possibly be a real service dog?  What happens if the person
explains the dog is a hearing dog or seizure alert dog?  Will the employee then
be allowed to refuse boarding based on their own opinion as to whether small
dogs might do service work?  What would stop someone with a psychiatric service
dog, or emotional support animal or pet for that matter, from lying about the
nature of the work their dog does?

The clearest evidence of whether a dog is truly a service dog is his
professionalism and demeanor and the credible verbal assurances of his handler,
without regard the questioner's personal biases about service dogs.

Title: Nathaniel C. Nerode
Comment:
My fiancee is disabled and I am very much in favor of strong accessability
requirements for trains.  However, the proposed regulations seem to have been
written by someone who has never been on a long train trip.  They should be
amended to reflect a better understanding of intercity trains.  In intercity
trains, level access to all cars is desirable and appropriate; but level
boarding of all cars is totally unnecessary for this, and costs a lot extra.

In an intercity train, the train cars are generally designed so that passengers
can walk -- *or wheel their wheelchairs* -- between cars.  This is in fact
crucial to accessibility, as passengers will want to travel to the lounge car,
or the cafe car or dining car.  The trips are long, so there is plenty of time
to travel to your seat or compartment from whatever car you enter in.  There is
no need to be able to level-board at all cars; if you can level-board at one,
designated point on the platform, and then walk level between cars, then you
have full level access to the entire train.

Where the cars on the train do *not* provide level travel between cars, and do
not need to provide such travel -- as with some bilevel commuter cars, where
there is no intercar travel and no cafe cars -- then it makes some sense to
require level boarding for all cars.  But where the trains *do* provide level
travel between cars -- which is more common -- and where the trips are of the
longer commuter and intercity lengths, it makes no sense at all.  

Amtrak currently has two classes of intercity trains.  The Superliners are
bilevel cars; passengers can travel level between cars at the upper level only,
and can board at the lower level only, at low platforms (15 inches above top of
rail).  The two levels are interconnected by stairs.  This is clearly not an
ADA-accessible design because it does not allow passengers to get from their
seats to the dining car.  It should be largely ignored for purposes of platform
design, as future trains should not be designed this way, and will not be
designed this way.  

As a side note, future ADA-accessible design requirements for intercity trains
should make level travel from one's seat to all amenities, like the dining and
lounge cars, a requirement; this is fairly straightforward to include in a
brand-new design (perhaps by including an "elevator car").

The second class of trains used by Amtrak are the single-level trains used on
the Northeast Corridor, the route from Chicago to Albany, and several other
routes with lower clearances.  These can be level-boarded from high platforms
(48 inches above top of rail) -- but they have full level travel between all
cars at all times.

Intercity trains are very long.  The proposed rule could require stations to
have 12-car or 15-car-long high platforms, which are very expensive compared to
low platforms with a short high-platform section.  And it would be utterly
pointless, because a station with a short 1-car-long high-platform, which is
much cheaper, would serve the same purpose: wheelchair access to all cars.  In
fact, historically intercity stations often have had platforms much shorter than
the trains which serve them, and board only through certain cars; passengers
then comfortably walk through the train to get to the other cars.  The proposed
rule would be akin to requiring an elevator for every staircase into a subway
station, rather than simply requiring elevator access to the station.

In addition, there are many stations which may need to be served both by trains
which level-board at high platforms, and trains which level-board at low
platforms.  This includes every station from Chicago through Cleveland
(currently served by both types of Amtrak trains).  What sort of platforms
should they have?  The most logical thing to do would be to provide full-length
level-boarding for low-level trains (which are less likely to have level passage
between cars), and one-or-two-car level boarding for high-level trains (which
will almost certainly have level passage between cars).  The proposed rule would
actually make it harder to make this sensible choice.

In summary, the proposed rule suffers from confusion between level *boarding*
and level *access*.
*Where a train allows for level travel between cars*, and the train trip is
*long enough* that the extra travel between cars is not a serious inconvenience,
then level boarding is only necessary at *one designated point on the platform*
in order to achieve the *actual goal*, which is *level access* to all cars.

Please amend the rule to take account of this crucial issue.

Thank you for your time and attention.

people in a very uncomfortable predicament, since not everyone could shell out

people, single mothers with small children, single women traveling alone, none of 
whom could be imaginably made comfortable to spend the night in a terminal with 
no amenities.

This entire situation would have been dramatically improved had any one of the 
Norwest staff at the airport had enough training and leadership skills to deal 
properly with the situation.  Dealing with large numbers of passengers is not the 
exclusive territory of large metropolitan airports, and ALL airline staff should know 
how to handle customer service whether with one person or over a hundred.

Title: Coalition for an Airline Passengers Bill of Rights

Comment:
A serious concern for travelers or persons who remain immobile for long periods of 
time is the development of Deep Vein Thromboses.  According to the National 
Institute for Health Website, "The risk increases if the travel time is longer than 4 
hours, or if you have other risk factors for DVT.

During long trips, it may help to:

Walk up and down the aisles of the bus, train, or airplane. If traveling by car, stop 
about every hour and walk around. Move your legs and flex and stretch your feet to 
encourage blood flow in your calves. Wear loose and comfortable clothing. 
Drink plenty of fluids and avoid alcohol."1

For this important health reason, which can affect all travelers, the proposed 
regulation must not permit delays or confinement for any time greater than four 
hours, must ensure that during any delay passengers are permitted to move freely 
about the cabin, and must be provided with adequate non-alcoholic fluids at no 
cost to the passengers.  Failure to provide passengers with this could lead to 
DVT.  

Consequences of DVT can include pulmonary embolisms, damage to the lungs 
other organs or death. 2

1 http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/dci/Diseases/Dvt/DVT_Prevention.html
2 http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/dci/Diseases/Dvt/DVT_WhatIs.html

Comment:
The regulations do not explicitly prohibit a practice I see today on several
airline sites that leaves consumers with incomplete information.  When a flight
is "operated by" another carrier (such as a regional carrier), I often see no
information on that flight, but only the carrier's so-called "mainline" flights
it directly operates.  My preferred carrier, USAirways, currently operates their
site in this manner, where I can only see one flight's statistics listed, but
not the second leg of my flight on their regional carrier.   Therefore, I
propose that rulemaking require a carrier to list performance statistics for ALL
flights it tickets through its site, whether it be by code-share, sub-contracted
carrier, etc.

I also propose that 3 hours is unacceptably short period for a carrier to allow
passengers to be essentially hostage. Airlines also must be held accountable to
a standard of being a business. Every plane delayed contains passengers, often
on business, where the delay of that passenger's business has a direct or
indirect impact on that passenger's livelihood, often manyfold beyond the cost
of the airfare.  Even if the proposed maximum is shortened, the regulations
should be written that provide the passenger with rights to:

1. Beverages (non-alcoholic) shall be provided for free, even if the airline
customarily charges for them. At least 1 serving, per hour of the delay.

Reasoning: Passengers with certain health conditions require hydration at least
once per hour.

2. Use of any and all accceptable electronic devices during a substantial delay,
including mobile telephony, until the aircraft is the #5 aircraft in taxi line
for takeoff, or less than 15 minutes to takeoff, as ascertained by the captain.  

Reasoning:
This is particularly important for passengers who could possibly call into a
meeting, and not miss it completely because of airline electronic sterile-cabin
rules being enforced unnecessarily.  Passengers might also wish to modify other
travel plans, as a result of the delay, and would wish to accomplish this while
onboard the delayed plane, rather than waiting until arrival at destination. 
Current cabin rules on electronics are unacceptable during delays, and current
policy of crew discretion should not be a passenger's only option.

3. Reasonable Reaccommodation to destination: If the aircraft is delayed at the
gate, and has been delayed in pushback from gate or gate areas more than 30
minutes by any mechanical delays, customers should be allowed to request
accommodation to board another flight(s) on the same airline, departing from the
same airport, at their choosing, with no financial penalty or fee, so long as
the non-delayed flight has seating capacity. The regulation should require this
option be made available, so long as the alternate flight(s) are scheduled to
depart more than 1 hour after the delayed flight's original departure time.  If
necessary, passengers should also be allowed to opt for connecting flight(s) to
their original destination, at no financial penalty or fee, even if their
original and delayed flight was a non-stop flight.

Reasoning:   This is just common sense. If another flight gets the passenger to
their destination in a more certain or opportunistic way or schedule for the
passenger, it should be their right and choice.

4. Airlines shall be prohibited from boarding the aircraft when a known "no-fly"
maintenance issue is in progress, until a reasonable time for resolution can be
guaranteed that does not delay the flight by more than 30 minutes. Passengers
should be notified of the maintenance, and offered to be re-accommodated with
alternate reservations at no additional costs, if the passenger so chooses, and
seats are available.  

Reason: Countless travelers such as myself would take another flight option, if
the delayed flight could be avoided before I was on-board.  It is unacceptable
for an airline to board and delay passengers, when the condition existed on last
flight of the aircraft, and it is known before boarding has even begun.  To
force customers to board is an unacceptable practice, regardless of the
airline's ground-crew availability, scheduling, or other labor / profitability
concerns that may be mentioned by airline comments. Passengers often have 
other
flight options, and would choose to use them, if airlines were more honest and
transparent about delay potential. Business travelers on refundable fares, would
want to exercise this option, for example, just to change over to another flight
without the problems.

Title: Sophia Bellardi
Comment:
As a travel agent with over 38 years of experiance, in the increasingly irritating 
field of travel, I cannot understand why anyone in any branch of Cobgress would 
not be for EACH and EVERY provision that would make the airlines accountable 
to the traveling public.  Even I, a long time travel agent, refuse to travel unless 
absolutely necessary---think of what this hesitation does to our economy, each 
and every year.

Title: David
Comment:
Length of delays is not the only problem. The destruction to our personal property 
is despicable. They have little or no regard for our luggage. Wheels ripped off, "we 
are not responsible for damaged wheels". Let's see them try to pull several cases 
through an airport with no wheels. I get about 6 flights out of a suitcase if I am 
lucky. They can demolish a case in one flight. If they break a tool box they dump 
it into a blue bin. Nothing comes to you like you gave it to them. I wonder how 
they would like a keyboard with a few keys missing. I am not responsible for 
missing keys. If damaged their equipment like they destroy mine, I would be in 
jail !!! Something needs to change.

Title: Stephen J. Weihman
Comment:
Was this written by the airline industry?  How can the wording of a "binding" 
regulation have so many "may's" and "should's".  To be worth the paper it's written 
on, it should state what the airlines "must" do, no give them suggestions of what 
they might do.  If you can't do that, quit wasting our tax dollars on yet another 
unenforceable, non-binding legal document that the airlines will ignore completely.

Title: Luke S. Szulczewski
Comment:
The wording of this document is weak and unenforcable.  It is time to put a stop to 
the hours people are sometimes forced to sit in a plane.  Also there should be 
penalties for airlines that don't follow the rules.  Lets rewrite this and leave out the 
word "may" and use "will or must".  With the airline industry at it's lowest point it 
is obvious that the airlines can not regulate themselves.  Time to have the federal 
government step in and force them to change.

Title: John R. Cordner
Comment:
There is too much permissive language (ie: "may," "should") rather than 
mandatory requirements in these regs.

Airlines have shown, on several occasions, that they simply can not be trusted to 
look after the welfare of those held prisoner aboard their aircraft.  If an airline can 
not afford to behave responsibly during an extended tarmac delay, then that airline 
should be allowed to go out of business!

It's time for the Government to stop coddling the airlines.  Fines should be 
imposed for airlines mistreating their customers.  Aircraft crew should be subject 
to prison terms if they hold passengers, against their will, for more than two hours.

Title: Stanley Joseph Pruszynski
Comment:
By allowing airlines to provide lip service to guidelines that they "should" but are 
not "required" to adhere to makes this entire document useless to the traveling 
public which has been subjected to callous and uncaring treatment by airlines 
whose only concern is what will make them the most money or what will cost 
them the least penalty. Airlines MUST be required to provide information, options 
to deplane or not board at all, or compensate passengers for their negligent 
actions in holding passengers hostage for hours on planes sitting on the tarmac all 
over the country. Either make it enforceable or don't waste time creating a 
document that airlines can ignore with impunity.

Title: Patrick Wood
Comment:
In general, I approve of these new regulations; however, I feel that some of the
language is weak.  "May" and "should" are often used, instead of "will" or
"must".  Voluntary compliance is useless, as the airlines have consistently
given short shrift to passengers' rights (or lack thereof) when there are any
associated costs involved.  In particular, by allowing airlines to pick and
choose their level of compliance, you will force those airlines that really want
to comply with most or all of your rules to cut back when others don't, due to
cost considerations.  Requiring compliance levels the playing field
economically, forcing all airlines to incur the same costs, thereby preventing a
cascading effect when one and then another decide to forego implementation to
cut costs.

Making these rules mandatory and legally binding, with increasing fines for
noncompliance, is the only way to see them implemented across all airlines in
all economic conditions.

Title: Aaron E. Ross
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern,

I'm disappointed by the lack of enforcable language in this document. Nothing in
the recent history of the airline industry suggests that airlines will
voluntarily act to reduce ground delays.

Rather, commercial pressures will continue to force them to keep planes away
from the gates as long as possible, in the hopes they will soon be in the air.

Be setting strong, enforcable rules you can create shared market conditions that
will force airlines and airports to work together to develop commercially viable
solutions that work for airlines and passengers.

Thank you for you attention.

Aaron Ross

Title: Eric W. Hoyer
Comment:
Are you kidding me?? These requirements are not strict enough. Airline 
passengers deserve better than this.

We need real substantial protections to push the airlines to make improvements 
in performance. These requirements also need to be legally binding on the 
airlines. The wording needs to be tougher to make these plans not optional, and 
enforceable.

Please provide the change that is needed to bring the protections and assistance 
that airline passengers need.

Thank you,
Eric Hoyer

Title: Jose Campos
Comment:
The root cause of the ground delays is not only the weather, which is the
favorite excuse of the industry and likely not the number one reason.

First the airlines knowingly schedule more flights than the rated capacity of
airports, which not surprisingly, creates congestion and thus ground delays. 
The reduction in personnel below the minimum to provide the right level of
service is another.

In short, let's not allow the airlines to pull-the-wool-over-our-eyes with
tired, old "sound bites".

Root cause analysis is a mature, tried and true methodology that can get at the
bottom of the incompetence and arrogance of the airlines.  A methodical analyis
of the reasons for ground delays will yield very valuable information; although,
information which the airlines already know.

Title: Michael Dawson
Comment:
Comments regarding NPRM for D.O.T. 49CFR Part 39
Docket # OST 2007 268299
ADA Passenger Vessels

St. George's School operates Geronimo, a Sailing School Vessel (Subchapter R) 
in
the waters between New England and the Caribbean. We typically sail with a total
complement of ten persons onboard. Our school has demonstrated a strong 
support
for the ADA in it’s recent history, but concede that there are circumstances
that preclude some of our students from sailing aboard Geronimo. We make this
decision based on the safety and well-being of all persons on board and the
compatibility of our program with an individual’s particular circumstance. 

In response to sections 39.25, our vessel is quite small, with little room on
deck, and can only accommodate 13 total persons on board at any time. Being
required to accommodate disabled persons on board would prove, not just
challenging, but sometimes impossible in the interest of safety. Although our
vessel was designed in close cooperation with the USCG to comply with current
regulations and safety considerations, we simply are not able to accommodate all
disabled individuals. 

In light of the fact that a significant part of our program involves individuals
on our vessel embarking and debarking via a small inflatable boat, it would
significantly alter the nature of our program, in terms of program content and
operating area. We support the clause proposed in section 39.21(b), that makes
exceptions for vessels that would “fundamentally alter” their operation in
complying with said regulations.

I believe that the proposed regulations are not compatible with a vessel of our
size and purpose, and are clearly not compatible with the sustainability of our
program. 

Respectfully,

Michael Dawson
Captain – SSV Geronimo
St. George's School

Title: Frank Barton
Comment:
My family operates the TUNICA QUEEN riverboat and we operate on the Mississippi 
River in the Tunica, MS area. We offer sightseeing and dinner cruises 9 months a 
year. We have 7 full employees and approximately 35 part time employees. We do 
experience a high turnover rate due to the seasonality of our business. Our average 
passenger load per trip is less than 50. As you can tell by this overview, we are a very 
small family owned business and 

ADA TRAINING: Very few of my employees have formal education with regards to 
maritime training. The bulk of employees are service staff that work other jobs as 
bartenders and waiters. Because of this and the previously mentioned high turnover 
rate, it will quite difficult to conduct formal ADA training and be able to maintain ADA 
trained staff. To require formal ADA training for employees that interact with our 
passengers will create a tremendous burden on our operation and will be ineffective 
because of the high turnover rate.

TTY REQUIREMENT: At this time we do not know if TTY services are available to our 
rural area. We urge to determine the availability and cost of this service before making 
it a requirement. We do not use internet sites to sell tickets to passengers. 

 
LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF DISABLED PASSENGERS: In reviewing the proposed 
rule it appears that it was based on larger passenger vessels like cruise ships. Rather 
than using a specific number as a limiting factor we suggest that a sliding scale based 
the vessel capacity be reviewed.
 
MANDATORY COMPANY ADA COMPLAINT RESOLUTION OFFICIALS and VESSEL 
ADA COMPLAINT RESOLUTION OFFICIALS: This proposal appears to have come 
straight from the commercial airline industry and while it might be appropriate for and 
operation like Carnival Cruise Lines, it is totally inappropriate for our small company. 
We cannot afford this additional cost burden. As a small family owned business, any 
complaint regarding any issue is handled my wife or me. We are capable of dealing 
with ADA complaints as well. On board our vessel, our Captain has the necessary 
experience to deal with any possible problems, as he has done throughout his career. 

Propriety of Crew Assistance in Boarding/Deboarding: Our crew is quite competent in 
assisting passengers with boarding and deboarding when needed and they have the 
necessary training for dealing the nuances of our vessel. They must be allowed to 
continue to perform these functions for the safe operation of our vessel. 
 

In closing, please?.please review the practical aspects of these proposed rules before 
implementing them. This is not a case of one size fits all. 


Frank Barton
Delta Riverboat Company, LLC
Tunica Queen Riverboat

Title: Water Emergency Transportation Authority
Comment:
The Water Emergency Transportation Authority (WETA) is a state sanctioned 
regional authority tasked with implementing new public commuter ferry service 
within the San Francisco Bay Area as well as serving as a conduit for the region 
during disasters or emergencies.  WETA is concerned about the detail imposed 
on passenger vessels as it appears that the language is intended for large cruise 
ships as opposed to our small 149 passenger-only vessels.  
1.  Should vessel personnel be required to have training in ADA and accessibility 
matters?  Although not currently in the proposed rule, it is understood that DOT is 
considering same.  A formal ADA training course with certification is not 
customary within the small passenger-only industry.  A company developed 
customer service training which includes ADA is the norm.
2.  TYY and other information Services:  DOT asks whether the rule should be 
amended to incorporate accessibillity standards for vessel company web pages.  
WETA urges DOT not to address this question in the passenger vessel 
rulemaking; but, addess same in a future rulemaking applicable to web sites of all 
types of businesses, not just the passenger vessel industry.
3.  Possible limitations on number of disabled Passengers/advance notice 
requirements:  The DOT proosed rule does allow a 72-hour "advance notice" 
requirement for a group of 10 or more passengers with disabilities.  DOT was 
considering large curise ships with hundreds or even thousands of passengers 
when this 10-person group exception was developed.  This could be challenging for 
our small 149 passenger vessels.  Suggest DOT impose a "sliding scale" for the 
size of a group for vessels with relatively lower passenger capacities.
4.  Should company ADA complaint resolution officials and vessel ADA complaint 
resolution officials be mandatory?  This proposal is based on the exsiting 
commercial airline model.  WETA won't have the typical resources, number of 
employees, or management structure equivalent to the typical billion dollar airline 
industry.  WETA will employ a feasible and reasonable program to deal with 
customer complaints of all kinds with ADA being one of many.
5.  Propriety of crew assistance in boarding/deboarding.  DOT has expressed an 
interest in this question and has indicated that it anticipates that crew assistance 
will be both appropriate and necessary in certain instances (although it should not 
be veiwed as the customary method of boarding individuals with disabilities.)
WETA strongly states that the rule must allow for crew assistance where 
appropriate.  This is a safety issue.  Safety is paramount as slips, trips, and falls 
are among the most common causes of injuries for all passengers whether 
possessing a disability or not.  Many technically non-disabled passengers request 
crew assistance in boarding and disembarking; consequently, this is not a matter 
of discrimination againsts those with disabilities.  Safety of crew members is also 
a factor and there can be some situations where crew assistance is neither 
possible nor safe, e.g., attempting to lift passengers in heavy motorized chairs or 
scooters.
Thank you for the opportunity to submit comments to the proposed rulemaking.

Title: Bridgeport/ Port Jefferson Steamboat Company
Comment:
The Bridgeport and Port Jefferson Steamboat Company (BPJ) offers the following 
in response to the request for comments on proposed rule making in the matter of 
ADA-Passenger vessels:

BPJ, a company founded in 1883, offers ferry service across Long Island Sound 
between Bridgeport Connecticut and Port Jefferson NY. The service operates on a 
year round basis and utilizes three passenger/vehicle ferries with passenger 
capacities of 1000 persons each. Two of the vessels can carry up to 120 vehicles 
and the third up to 90 vehicles. Utilization in 2007 was approximately one million 
passengers and approximately four hundred sixty thousand vehicles.
BPJ is a small business as defined by the Small Business Administration with 
peak season employment in the 175-200 range with winter employment 
substantially lower.
Regarding the question as to whether vessel personnel should receive special 
training on matters pertaining to ADA and accessibility, our company has the 
expectation of our personnel that they endeavor to assist ALL passengers 
regardless of ability or disability as a need presents. Such expectations should 
cover the intent of the goals of any special training. This, we believe, is consistent 
with the requirements of safety aboard ship, good customer service and maritime 
tradition. It is unfortunate that the strong possibility exists that offers of assistance 
could be misinterpreted as somehow a ?violation? of a regulation. That said, should 
the DOT, or any other agency, develop a short, easily assimilated pamphlet or 
guideline on ADA and accessibility, such material would be welcome indeed.
With respect to text telephones (TTY) doesn?t a combination of website 
availability, telephone option and printed material cover the intent of information 
and reservation accommodation? Further, we believe that the DOT should hold in 
abeyance a decision on web accessibility as this is an issue that pertains to 
businesses of every kind, not just to passenger vessel operators.
With respect to the establishment of company ADA complaint officials and the 
same aboard vessels, we believe that complaints of this nature should be handled 
in the same way that all complaints are handled. In our company, complaints of 
any nature are investigated with the goal of resolution. This is consistent with 
sound business practice and good customer service. Additionally, it is our belief 
that resolving issues, including accessibility issues, can contribute to greater 
utilization of our service and revenue enhancements.
With respect to the propriety of assistance in boarding or disembarking, we again 
refer to the maritime tradition of helping all customers, both able and disabled 
where required and with regard for safety. Marine operators frequently assist 
passengers, again able and disabled, in moving on, off or about a vessel. One can 
envision a scenario where a crew member might hesitate to assist someone 
based on fear of violating a regulation. This would serve neither letter nor the intent 
of accessibility regulations.

Title: Lake Michigan Carferry
Comment:
April 22, 2008

Passenger Vessel Operational Requirements under the ADA Act

Ladies and Gentlemen:

Lake Michigan Carferry is a small business and a member of the Passenger 
Vessel Association.  The following comments are in response to your efforts to 
impose operational requirements to all passenger vessels for the DOT ADA rule.  
Lake Michigan Carferry operates the S.S. Badger. The Badger was built in 1952-
53 by the Christy Corporation in Sturgeon Bay, WI and put into service in March of 
1953. Since 1992, the Badger has been in service transporting leisure travelers, 
their vehicles and commercial trucks between Ludington, MI and Manitowoc, WI   
Lake Michigan Carferry is a team of dedicated people committed to expanding our 
100-year car ferry heritage by providing a unique travel experience enhanced by 
superior customer service.  The Badger is a Registered State Historic Site in both 
Michigan and Wisconsin.  The coal fired steam engine propulsion system is 
designated a Mechanical Engineering Landmark by the National Society of 
Mechanical Engineers.   The Badger is a continuation of a vital maritime tradition, 
and we celebrate that heritage by offering a rare opportunity for our passengers to 
enjoy a little history - and a lot of fun.
Our sailing season is from mid-May to mid-October.  At the peak of our season, 
we employ up to 230 employees, half of which hold positions on shore in 
Ludington and Wisconsin.  Aside from approximately 25 employees that work 
through the winter in the corporate office or winter work aboard the Badger, the 
rest of our employees are summer workers.  Our sailing season fits so well with 
college and high school schedules, a large majority of our employees are 
students between the ages of 18 and 22.      
The Badger transports approximately 100,000 passengers, 30,000 autos and 1200 
commercial trucks per season.  The route from Ludington, MI to Manitowoc, WI is 
60 miles, approximately four hours en route.  We have 50-60 crewmembers 
aboard for each trip.
Potential requirement for training in ADA and accessibility.   The crew of the 
Badger consists of both licensed and rated personnel, pursuant to the 
requirements of the Coast Guard.  Outside of our Navigation and Engine 
crewmembers, all other employees do not attend formal courses for maritime 
training.  The students that are hired for the summer season have the most 
interaction with our passengers.    We conduct mandatory safety training 
sessions each season for all crewmembers.  CPR training is required for all 
crewmembers in a supervisory position.  Customer Service training is required for 
all new hires.   A formal ?ADA training course? with certification is not in keeping 
with our current schedule of training sessions.  As a large majority of our 
employees are students, the longevity of their employment is, at the most, one or 
two seasons.  Due to scheduling restraints and the small window of opportunity of 
time that we have with our employees, additional training would create a hardship 
for our company and extra burden to the preparation of our season.   
TTY and other Information Services  The reservation system that we have does not 
currently provide this service.  When a reservationist receives a call from a hearing 
impaired customer, the customer will make the call using operator assistance.  
This allows the hearing impaired person to use a TTY phone on their end.  This 
has proven to be a successful way of communicating with the hearing impaired 
customer and has never been a deterrent or a point of concern.
Historic Vessels  The S.S. Badger and her sister ship the S.S. Spartan were the 
last ? and largest ? coal fired, steam engine carferries built in the U.S.  The 
Badger being the only one of the two that is operational offers an authentic 
historical experience to our passengers.  The engines are two Skinner Unaflow 4-
cylinder steam, rated 3,500 hp at 125 rpm.  The boilers are four Foster-Wheeler ?D-
type?, burning domestic bituminous coal.  The services and activities that are 
offered on each voyage are unique to the history of the Badger and have grown to 
be expected by each and every passenger.  The proposed modifications would 
be ?unduly burdensome? and would ?require a fundamental alteration? to the nature 
of the services and activities that we provide. 
Should Company ADA Complaint Resolution Officials and Vessel ADA Complaint 
Resolution Officials be mandatory?    With every trip across the lake, our 
passengers are handed a ?customer comment card? and encouraged to comment 
on the services they received and suggestions they may have.   We value what 
our passengers have to say and take stock in their suggestions.  Complaints are 
handled in a timely manner by the Cruise Director that is on duty during that 
voyage.  We believe that the personal attention our passengers receive from the 
LMC staff is one of the many unique aspects of sailing on the Badger.  Any 
questions or concerns regarding ADA issues would be handled by the personnel 
with the most knowledge on the subject.  To date we have had very few, if any, 
ADA complaints.
 Propriety of Crew Assistance in Boarding/Deboarding  Our crewmembers are not 
only expected to assist passengers when necessary, but they are encouraged to 
assess every situation for the possibility of slips, trips and falls whether the 
passenger is disabled or not.   We provide a chair-lift for passengers that are 
wheel-chair bound and we offer the chair-lift to any passenger who feels they are 
unable to use the stairs to board the Badger.
Thank you for this opportunity to participate and voice our opinions in this 
rulemaking process.
Respectfully,
Bob Manglitz			Don Clingan
President/CEO			V.P. Marketing 
				& Shore Customer Service

Title: Lindblad Expeditions
Comment:
Lindblad Expeditions operates two 152? US flagged small passenger vessels that 
carry 62 overnight passengers and 24 crewmembers.  The National Geographic 
Sea Bird was constructed in 1981 and the National Geographic Sea Lion in 1982.  
The vessels are inspected by the US Coast Guard under Subchapter K of Title 46 
CFR.  The vessels operate year round in Southeast Alaska, the Pacific Northwest, 
the Columbia and Snake Rivers and Baja California.  Trips are generally 7 day 
long ?expedition style? voyages in remote areas of the regions we travel focusing 
on Natural History.  Shore landings are done via 19? Zodiac inflatable boats for the 
purpose of offering guided hikes.  Passengers are also offered opportunities for 
kayaking in one and two person sea kayaks.  Snorkeling is offered in Baja 
California.

Given the nature of our operation (i.e. landing people in remote locations on shores 
where no facility exists and taking them on hikes through rugged terrain) we are 
particularly concerned about Section 39.21(b).  We specifically support the 
retention of the ?fundamentally alter/undue burden? clause in the proposed section.

The Master of the Vessel deals with any complaints on board made by our 
guests.  They attempt to address any concerns in a way that satisfies the guest 
without compromising safety or security.  However, due to the size and date of 
construction of our vessel there area some complaints which cannot be resolved 
(e.g. the size of a cabin, removing furniture built into the ship, etc.)  Any 
complaints which are unable to be resolved on board are dealt with by our Guest 
Services Department.  Any complaints, regardless of the nature, are handled the 
same way.  While we acknowledge that some senior Company personnel will 
need to have a basic level of understanding of the responsibilities imposed on a 
vessel operator by the ADA, we suggest that accessibility complaints be handled 
in the same way as all other complaints.

Lastly, regarding the issue of crew assistance there are many occasions in our 
operation where crew assistance is necessary for the safety of both the guests 
and crew, whether they are disabled or not.  For example, when transferring from 
the ship into the inflatable Zodiacs we currently require ALL (crew and guests) to 
take the hand of two other individuals to assist.  Our vessels are certified for 20 
nautical miles off shore and consequently are frequently subject to extreme motion 
in inclement weather.  In these occasions crew often have to assist guests about 
the ship.  Conversely, there are also some situations where it is unsafe for crew to 
provide assistance (e.g. attempting to lift passengers in scooters or move them up 
and down steep stairways in rough weather).  The rule must allow for crew 
assistance where it is deemed appropriate in order to ensure the safety of not only 
our guests, but also our crew.

Title: Troy M. Manthey, Yachet Starship Dining Cruises
Comment:
Yacht Starship Dining Cruises is a small business that operates 2 passenger 
vessels in Tampa and Clearwater Florida.  Starship employees 50 full time 
employees and another 25-75 seasonal empoyees.  Our cruises consist primarily 
of lunch, brunch and dinner cruises.  We operate year round, however our volume 
of business greatly varies in the different seasons; Spring, Summer, Fall and 
Winter.  The seasonal nature of our business results in a large turnover of 
employees. The  largest dining yacht in our fleet carries 600 passengers and is 
one of the only yachts in its class to have an elevator, built in 1999.  The smallest 
dining yacht carries 150 passengers.

In regards to personnel being trained in ADA accessability matters, we think the 
primary responsibility remains with the Captain of the Yacht.  The USCG licensed 
Captain has the responsiblity to train all crew members for all safety conditions.  
Which include the safe loading and discharging of passengers with disabilities.  
With the many different docks, gangways and tide heights Starship no one 
situation is the same. Boarding and Disembarking of all passengers is the 
responsibility of the Captain and its under his/her direct supervision that this take 
place.  Yacht Starship's safety record and experience with handling passengers 
with disabilities speaks for itself and does not mandate any additional training.

We oppose text telephone messaging for passengers with hearing disabilitites.  
The cost are unknown and in 7-years of operation and 500,000 passengers carried 
to my knowledge we have not had one request for text messaging.

We support any provision that requires advance notice for passengers with 
disabilities.  Vessels are weight sensitive and a disabled passenger may travel 
with equipment that substantially adds to the weight of the passenger.  Each 
vessel has a maximum allowable weight (calculated on a per passenger basis) 
and the Captain must take any additional weight over and above the normal weight 
and subtract it from the total passengers allowed.  Generally the smaller the 
vessel the greater the affect of additional weight from a disabled passenger 
traveling with a lot of support equipment.  Total passengers carried may have to be 
reduced in the event of passengers boarding with substantial additional weight (i.e. 
electric wheelchair), therefore notice should be required.

Yacht Starship docks at undeveloped remote barrier islands along the Florida 
Coast and uses temporary gangways for offloading.  Sometimes placing 
passengers in six inches to 1 feet of water upon offloading and loading.  We 
cannot accomodate passengers with disabilities when operating at these remote 
islands.  We oppose any requirement for accessiblitiy at these remote locations.

ADA complaints should be responded in the same format that we currently 
address customer complaints.  This varies from complaint to complaint based on 
the format (phone, email, fax, written, verbal) of the complaint.  This should be left 
up to the company to respond as it would any other complaint.

We strongly support the crew assisted boarding and disembarking for all 
passengers on our Yachts.  The safe boarding, disembarking and movement of 
passengers is the responsibility of the Captain.  All passenges are evaluated and 
the appropriate assistance is provided.  We currenlty provide more assistance to 
children and elderly passengers than passengers with disabilities.  Please do not 
discourage the safe boarding/disembarking by making any changes to current 
system managed by the Captain of the vessel.

Should you have any questions I am available at your convenience.

Sincerely,

Captain Troy Manthey
President and CEO
Yacht Starship Dining Cruises

Title: Barry P. King
Comment:
I, Barry King, am submitting these comments with regard to the impact of the proposed rule making 
on the operation of sailing vessels certificated as passenger vessels.  My wife and I own and 
operate a traditional sailing vessel, the schooner Mary Day, offering week long overnight adventure 
vacations along remote sections of the Maine coast. 

Since I submitted my first comments another summer tourist season has come and gone.  This 
year I have some employees returning and a few new employees as well.  Once again I am in the 
cycle of preparing my crew to safely sail a large vessel with no inboard engine.  Once again we are 
drilling to keep ourselves and our guests safe.  In 8 weeks time this crew will have been through a 
very rigorous training program that includes over 2,000 people hours of maintenance for only a 4 
month revenue generating season.  

I am overwhelmed as I reflect upon the idea that this rule making process may some day require 
this young crew to learn sign language, for instance, or deal with disabilities far beyond the 
practicable means of our current level of service.  The idea that we shall lose the discretion as to 
which disabilities we can safely accommodate in this remote environment seems counter-intuitive.  
The Maine windjammer fleet, composed of 14 historic vessels, some of which are National Historic 
Landmarks, has never turned away reasonable requests for passage from people with disabilities.  
To take away the discretionary powers that the Coast Guard has authorized us to use seems to pit 
one set of federal regulations against another.  Would it not make sense to give small passenger 
vessels the ability to conform where practicable after the Access Board has determined design 
standards for these historic sailing vessels and the disabilities they can safely accommodate on 
discetionary adventure travel vacations?  And when will the SBA have its opportunity to justify that 
the expense these "mom and pop" businesses will face is not an undue burden?  Once again I 
invite anyone to come tour our vessels and see first hand the incredible treasure that is the historic 
Maine windjammer sailing fleet found here on the Maine coast and no where else in America.  

While some members of lobbying groups may send form letters lacking any real insight into the 
passenger vessels industry, masters of traditional sailing vessels speak from practical experience 
and genuine concern for the public we serve.  To quote a few of the first round comments "More and 
more people are coming home with disabilities. Please give these people and all those with 
disabilities the respect they deserve. Make the world more accessible to all!" "I support that all 
cruises company USA and International must provide interpreter and close caption on all cruises. 
Please listen."   While I admire these comments in their intent they offer nothing in the way of 
practical experience with passenger vessels, let alone historic and traditional sailing vessels. At 
what point in time does it makes sense to legislate that all passenger vessels, regardless of means 
of propulsion and all that entails (i.e. angle of incline under normal operating circumstances) must 
accommodate all disabilities with absolutely no regard for the way we operate our vessels in an 
environment that does not discriminate and cannot be tamed by a simplistic and linear rule making 
process.  Asked directly, does lobbying group XYZ want to go sailing safely with knowledgeable 
crew that can safely operate a large traditional sailing vessel or sit at the dock while an intertpreter 
with no experience in traditional sail tells what it is like to feel the wind in the sails. While a crew 
member with broad interpretaive skills, a strong background in traditional sail, and great people 
skills is not impossible to find they are quite rare.  Qualified crew to operate these very unique 
vessels do not appear out of thin air nor can they be trained overnight.  Heck, it takes us at least 8 
weeks just to get themn a TWIC card from the TSA! Hiring additional crew is not financially 
feasible. Again I invite anyone from any lobby to examine my books and tell me how to find the 
money to pay additional crew while losing revenue generating capacity.  

In short, I ask that the DOT use a little common sense and honor practical experience when 
creating broad sweeeping rules that will impact small passenger vessels, traditional and historic 
sailing vessels in particular.  I would hope that those of us whose disabilities have yet to appear 
would deserve the same respect that those with current disabilities ask for in return.

Respectfully submitted,
Captain Barry King
Master, Owner and Operator
Schooner Mary Day

Title: U.S. Small Business Administration's Office of Advocacy
Reg White, Paradise Cruise, Ltd of Honolulu, Hawaii
John C. Foss
Comment:
My name is John C .Foss and I have been a licensed passenger vessel operator 
and owner since 1969 in the Maine windjammer business. Most of the vessels in 
the small fleet up here have earned national Landmarkstatus while retaimning 
current passenger vessel certificates. This is a remarkable achivement that these 
mostly 19th century American merchant vessels meet Coast Guard safety 
standards while being judged by national experts as being historically accurate.

While accomodating disabled persons in public transportation is a basic right, 
some passenger vessels because of their intended use, size, or approved design 
should be exempted from common carrier disability access for the following 
reasons:

1. Small sailing vessels conducting multi day cruises offer an elective vacation in 
which there is an implied a level of mobility, as an integral part of the outdoor 
adventure nature of the experience. In the normal course of their operation sailing 
vessels react to  random forces of wind in strength and direction, causing the craft 
to heel ( incline) and demonstrate irregular motion. The value of the experience 
offered to passengers involves some physical agility, whether in negociating the 
ladders to cabins and facilities below decks, in boarding small boats to row 
ashore,or in landing on deserted beaches or at docks in small fishing harbors we 
visit along the coast. 

2. As National Historic Landmarks, many of the Maine windjammers are subject 
to period review to maintain their landmark status. Thisd is a hard won honor and 
reflects national signifigance. Any modification to meet new accessiblity 
standards would very likely challenge this historic status. Obliging small wooden 
vessels to install ramps, lifts, power driven machinery for access, lower thresholds 
in violation of presdent watertight safety standards.. all these possible impositions 
to address ADA demands would challenge the character and viablitiy and 
authenticity of these unique passenger vessels.

3. The outdoor  nature of windjammer cruises on the Maine coast means that the 
small harbors and conservation islands visited by our passengrs for shore 
explorations are not and in most cases cannot be made handicapped accesible. 
The average tidal range in this area is ten feet: ramps and docks do not meet the 
incline parameters for disability access. Adapting shore landings on national or 
state parks or conservation islands for handicap access would spoil the nature of 
these preserved places.

4. Vessels not engaged as common carriers and not recieving state or federal 
subsidies should be viewed differenetly from ferries that are part of government 
transportation systems.

5. A lower limit breakpoint of 49 ovenight passengers and 100 tons register (Coast 
Guard regulations subchapter T) would be a reasonable upper limit for any new 
ADA regulations for small passneger vessels.

Thank you, 

John C. Foss

Comment:
I urge you to vocally oppose potential mergers among the nation's major airlines 
for the following reasons:

Hubs Will Be Eliminated
All the major airlines operate a hub and spoke system. A combination of two or 
more airlines will create a redundancy of hubs, forcing the closure or substantial 
reduction in flights at some hubs. This will lead to a great loss of jobs at not only 
the airlines involved, but also at the dozens of service companies that support 
airline operations in hub cities. 

Service Frequency Will Be Reduced
If two airlines merge, frequency of flights between cities they both serve will be 
reduced. A major goal of airline mergers is to reduce capacity, which means fewer 
seats available for travelers.

Competition Will Be Diminished
Fewer airlines and fewer flights mean fewer choices for consumers. This leads to 
higher fares. 

Jobs Will Be Lost
Airline employees lost jobs after the 9/11 attacks.  They lost jobs after painful 
bankruptcies.  Mergers are just another avenue for airlines to cut even more jobs. 
This will lead to increased unemployment, as well as a reduction in taxes paid by 
airline workers and less money spent in their communities.

Customer Service Will Deteriorate Further
Customer service in the airline industry is legendary, legendarily poor. Merging 
two major airlines will force executives to pour resources into integrating the two 
companies and two different corporate cultures. This means customer service will 
not be a focus the combined airline.

Pension Obligations Will Be Jeopardized
Many airlines have frozen or terminated pension plans. If a merger takes place 
between two major airlines with company-sponsored pension plans, and the 
combined airline ultimately fails, the pensions will be forced onto the Pension 
Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC). If, for example, a Delta-Northwest 
combination failed, the PBGC would be burdened with more than $7 billion in 
liabilities. The PBGC has already expressed concerns about such a scenario.

A Merger Will Do Nothing to Lower Fuel Prices
Airlines cite high fuel prices as a reason to merge, but the cost of a gallon of fuel 
for two individual airlines will be the same as for one large airline. 

If airline executive spent as much time running the airline and improving their 
product as they do searching for the next big deal, the industry would be better for 
passengers, employees and the communities the airlines serve. I hope you will 
speak out against the consolidation of major U.S. airlines.

Title: T. M. Eden
Comment:
In the process of conferring with the Alabama Department of Public Safety and
the Alabama Trucking Association on the implementation of 40.331 (g), two issues
have arisen which may help to increase the broad acceptance and impact of the
interim final rule.  As I read 40.331 (g) it generally applies to all "service
agents", but the newly added (g) only allows an “employer” and “third-party
administrator for owner – operators of CMV drivers” to release a positive drug
test results, or other violations, to the State CDL licensing authorities. I
recommend that the language be revised to allow "Service Agents" to release
information to the State CDL licensing authorities. I make that recommendation
because there are only a handful of MRO's in each state typically assisting with
positive drug test reviews and the chances of a report being made by an MRO is
much more likely, with a higher degree of accuracy.  Actually Alabama would
prefer to receive the information directly from the MRO who is viewed as an
independent third-party professional.  Additionally, under the procedure which
Alabama is considering, a SAP or MRO may need to be in a position to release
information to the State CDL licensing authorities relative to license
reinstatement and continued compliance with follow-up testing.  Alabama is
considering a procedure whereby upon receipt of notice of a positive drug test,
the CDL driver’s license is temporarily suspended and reinstated on a medically
restricted basis once a negative return to duty test has been very performed and
reported to the State CDL licensing authorities.  The CDL driver would then be
issued a medically restricted CDL license with the restriction being removed
upon notification of the successful completion of follow-up testing. Because
many times these positive drug test drivers have been terminated by the
employer, it is critical to allow other "service agents" to provide this notice
to the State CDL licensing authorities.  I am also aware that other positive
drug test state reporting statutes require reporting by the MRO.  My second
comment is that you also refer to "state regulations" and not just "state laws"
as you currently have.  If you will merely add "State laws and State
Regulations" that will allow Alabama to swiftly consider implementation of a
regulation. I wish to applaud your office for the innovative approach to help
States remove drunk and drugged drivers from the roadways of America. Tommy
Eden, Attorney, Capell & Howard, PC Montgomery, Alabama
As I propose the regulation would read as follows: 
40.331 (g) Notwithstanding any provision of this Part, Service Agents are
authorized to comply with State laws and State regulations requiring you to
provide to State CDL licensing authorities information about all violations of
DOT drug and alcohol testing rules (including positive drug test and refusals)
by any CMV driver holding a CDL, as well as information concerning a CDL
driver's subsequent compliance with return to duty and follow-up testing.
