Title: Jakob Helmboldt
Comment:
The document, A New Transportation Approach for America, is woefully 
inadequate given our current circumstances.  There is virtually no mention of non-
motorized modes save for the cursory mention of bike and pedestrian safety as 
one of 9 priority areas.  How can this be a priority if there isn't a single mention 
thereafter of bike and pedestrian modes?  Continued focus on only automobiles 
will do nothing to address the safety implications of non-motorized modes sharing 
the roadways, especially as their numbers increase as is being seen as a result 
of high gas prices.

Further, given the current gas prices, isn't it about time we actually got serious 
about facilitating and encouraging bicycling as a mode of transportation?  Our 
national infrastructure is so lacking in complete, connected and safe non-
motorized transportation networks that most people won't think twice about it as a 
mode of transport.  This document further ignores the matter, thereby continuing 
to give precedence to autos despite our continued claims that we need to reduce 
our depedence on private autos.

Lastly, the over-simplified consolidation of of the many programs now in existence 
into a relative handful of categories will not eliminate them, nor the need for 
separate programs and funding mechanisms.  It is simply a shell game 
constructed to make this plan look as though it cleans up a bureaucratic 
spiderweb of programs, funding streams, etc.  In reality they will simply become 
sub-categories and remain in existence.  It is akin to Homeland Defense, the 
biggest bureaucracy ever created, all under the guise of streamlining and 
downsizing of government.

Title: Peter Bowler
Comment:
The Honorable Secretary's Transportation Policy document cleverly 
titled: “Refocus. Reform. Renew.” contains many interesting ideas about how we 
should manage transportation in the United States in the future. However, it does 
not express anything like a guiding vision that one expects from a policy overhaul. 
The true focus of this document is the business of how we pay for transportation, 
not what or why we should do to plan for the next 25 years of transportation in our 
country.

The central point of the entire document appears to be the concept of removing the 
gasoline fuel tax as a primary way of funding highway maintenance. Along the 
way, it refers obscurely to the efficiencies of other modes and the need to 
alleviate “congestion” in our system. The “System” here is obviously primarily 
thought of as the Interstate highway System. It pays short shrift to other modes of 
rail, air, and transit. The “vision” really does not provide a roadmap for the future in 
any sort of clear terms. As a policy map, the document is as clear as the muddy 
Mississippi. The document reads like something an accountant would write after 
receiving orders to draft a funding strategy based on guidance provided by a “real” 
policy document.

I ask here: “did anyone in DOT actually read or comprehend all the myriad studies 
of capacity shortfalls either here already or soon to arrive for ALL modes”? Does 
anyone in DOT comprehend the implications and possible unintended 
consequences of demand pricing of highway use and deleting the fuel tax? Does 
anyone in DOT comprehend the need to reduce the use and conserve hydrocarbon 
fuels for all the reasons too obvious to enumerate here? I suspect DOT does 
understand all of these overriding issues, but why have they not addressed them 
point-by-point in terms of an overall Federal policy? 

Where is the vision for transit? Where is the vision for commuters? Where is the 
vision for alleviating the coming massive shortfall in rail freight capacity? Where is 
the vision for repairing and maintaining bridges? Where is the vision for building 
first class highways and bridges instead of the band aid approach we typically 
take in the United States? Does anyone in DOT comprehend that if you build it 
better, the overall cost to own may be significantly lower over the lifetime of the 
system than what we currently do?

I appreciate the amount of work it took to write the “policy” document, but as vision 
and policy for the future it is sadly lacking. Please try again, next time with a 
higher level perspective, then allow the accountants to take over and propose 
various alternatives to pay for the vision.

Peter Bowler

way to increase funding at the same time.  I think one thing that the government 
doesn’t take into account when it comes to transportation, is that transportation is 
an investment to the government and to the country.  Transportation is the life 
blood of the economy.  When we invest in transportation, we invest in the 
economy.  Lost dollars in the economy for commuting are saved.  Less time on 
the road means less fuel needed in our vehicles which is better for our environment 
and decreases our need for oil and energy.  Lost time for trucks and trains 
carrying freight is recovered, allowing more deliveries and lowering the costs for 
products.  More transportation construction projects means more jobs for all 
working class people, from the professional engineers (which I am) to the unskilled 
laborer.  And more capacity also means more growth, so that more businesses 
are built and more houses are erected.  I am in favor for a revenue increase in 
transportation, although I would be happy for starters if the gas tax would at least 
reflect the value of the dollar through inflation.  That would mean that the gas tax 
would keep up with inflation, in a similar fashion as the what the postal services 
are doing with the cost of stamps.

There is no other area that the government funds that sees as large of a return in 
its investment as the funding of transportation.  It is time that we streamline the 
way we work in the transportation industry to maximize its efficiency.  But it is 
also time to realize that funding transportation is a huge investment for the country 
that affects our lives in so many ways directly and indirectly, and we need to make 
sure that we increase the funding in a way that we maximize the investment.

Title: Carl
Comment:
This proposal is neither innovative nor forward looking, just more of the same use 
of technology that is over a century old. It says it will make highways safer, better 
maintained, and less congested with only the vague proposal to let states and 
municipalities solve the problem. Unfortunately, this is a problem much larger than 
any entity smaller than the federal government is likely to have much impact on. 
The proposed "Metropolitan Innovation Fund" seems to me like a sure way for the 
federal government to hand out more money with less accountability. Already we 
are spending twice as much to get three times as much congestion, does this 
mean we need to build the highways three times as large? No part of the proposal 
that I can discern addresses this. Safety seems to be another large issue but 
there are no proposals that would seem to significantly affect the mortality on our 
highways. There also seems to be some awareness that oil for fuel needs to be 
changed but again no proposals on the scale necessary to do anything about it. 
Technology will supposedly cure the above ills but how? If we were to automate 
the entire road/rail system in America, power it with wind and solar energy, and 
populate it with on-demand personal vehicles, all of the above problems would go 
away or at least be much reduced. All of he technology required is in use today, 
yet where is the discussion about doing this? Any real improvement to our nations 
transportation structure must be done by the federal government, otherwise many 
states and municipalities just will not do it, as should be obvious by our current 
problems. Finally, I agree the 13 year process is entirely too long, in that amount 
of time we should be well underway in building an automated system if people 
actually want to do something serious to address our problems.

NTSB reviews jet's skid landing at O'Hare 
By Alan Levin, USA TODAY

The pilots of an American Airlines flight carrying 185 passengers were
forced to make an unusual emergency landing last month in Chicago with
limited ability to control the jet after they lost electrical power,
according to newly released information from a federal investigation. 
The Boeing 757 skidded off a runway at O'Hare International Airport on
Sept. 22, the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) said. Although
none of the 192 people aboard was injured, the pilots flew on backup
battery power for long beyond the 30 minutes that their emergency
handbook said the batteries would last, the NTSB said. 

The pilots of the Seattle-to-New York flight drained the jet's battery
backup system, leaving inoperable vital systems that help stop a jet,
according to a preliminary report released this week. 

The pilots told investigators they had difficulty raising and lowering
the jet's nose and felt they had only one chance to land, the NTSB said.

"They should have landed as soon as practical," said Michael Barr, an
instructor at the University of Southern California's Aviation Safety
and Security Program. "That would have been the conservative approach. I
don't see why they thought they could fly all the way across country on
their backup electrical system."

The pilots had switched to battery power shortly after leaving Seattle
when electrical problems developed. The batteries last for about 30
minutes, but the pilots continued toward their destination until the
jet's electrical systems began failing about an hour and 40 minutes
later.

The need to land as soon as possible when aircraft systems begin to fail
has been reinforced by several accidents, such as Swiss Air Flight 111
in 1998, Barr said. The Swiss Air pilots attempted to diagnose where
smoke was coming from before deciding to divert, Canadian investigators
concluded. The jet became engulfed in fire and crashed off Nova Scotia,
killing all 229 people aboard. 

Last month, the American Airlines pilots had to stop the jet without
thrust reversers and other devices that help a jet stop, the NTSB said.
The electrical system failure was so complete that the pilots were
unable to shut off the engines after they came to a stop, the report
said. 

Barr said investigators will want to know what the airline's manuals and
emergency documentation instructed pilots to do, what the airline's
maintenance department advised the pilots to do and how pilots were
trained to handle electrical malfunctions. 

American and its pilots union, the Allied Pilots Association, declined
to comment while the case is under investigation.
